Posts.Content: I did, about three and a half years ago, and have just now exhaled. Your report sounds good, and now the treatment will begin. Always remember, "this too shall pass". We will all be behind you in the coming weeks/months/years to make sure you have plenty of support. Hugs, Judy
Posts.Title: Update-Good news

Posts.Content: Congratulations on your good news, and such a thing when the doctor can't wait to tell you. Hope you find even better news when you meet with him this week. Hugs. Judy
Posts.Title: Surgeon Just Called With News!!!!

Posts.Content: Suzanne, I also have had issues with my hair, and I finished treatment in October 2008 (TAC and 40 radiation treatments). I started Femara in August 2008, and my body just wouldn't let me take this med, so I was changed to Tamoxifen in December 2008. Today, my hair is still thin, and I continue to lose more and more each week. The beautician said you lose 10-18 hairs a day normally, so a little loss is expected. However, I, like you,don't see any new growth. I just keep it short, and it seems to cover the bald spots better that way. Scalp massage will help to "rejuvenate" the hair folicles, so maybe you can try massaging your scalp at night while reading or watching TV. The more massaging, the more awakening, according to my hair beautician. I have also started using Tea Tree Oil once a week, and do see some improvement. Overall, I am just happy to be alive to deal with this hair issue. If I wind up bald, then the wig goes back on. At least I am breathing, and enjoying a "hairless life". I hope you get some answers next week on your test for folicles. Hugs, Judy
Posts.Title: Finally saw dermatologist today about the hair thing

Posts.Content: One of the major assets I found as I was going through treatment was the assistance of a nutritionist. My cancer center has one on staff, and they were good enough to sit down and give me advice on what to eat, and when to eat, which, believe it or not, is very important. Even during chemo treatment, certain food types are helpful to give you more strength and energy. This was a big help for me, and I would suggest an inquiry at your oncologist's office to see if you can have access to this. I believe at my center that the nutritionist is available, but only if you ask for assistance. (Seems like it would be beneficial for everyone, but sometimes the system only works if you know how to use it.) Vitamins are a good source, but the "real thing" is better. Hugs to all. Judy
Posts.Title: New Article on Vitamin Study: Thoughts?

Posts.Content: My prayers go out to Carter and his family. I hate cancer too!! Just so unfair for someone so young to have to deal with this disease. There has got to be a cure out there soon. Hugs, Judy
Posts.Title: Prayers for Carter

Posts.Content: I have you in my thoughts and prayers...keep us posted. Hugs, Judy
Posts.Title: Ultrasound tomorrow

Posts.Content: This was just sent to me by a friend who is in the medical field, and she swears she has seen similar notes on patients records: No wonder so many people die in the hospitals. They're as bad as everything else! HOSPITAL CHART BLOOPERS (Actual writings from hospital charts) 1 . The patient refused autopsy. 2. The patient has no previous history of suicides. 3. Patient has left white blood cells at another hospital. 4. She has no rigors or shaking chills, but her husband states she was very hot in bed last night. 5. Patient has chest pain if she lies on her left side for over a year. 6. On the second day the knee was better and on the third day it disappeared. 7. The patient is tearful and crying constantly. She also appears to be depressed. 8 The patient has been depressed since she began seeing me in 1993. 9. Discharge status: Alive but without permission. 10. Healthy appearing decrepit 69-year old male, mentally alert but forgetful. 11. Patient had waffles for breakfast and anorexia for lunch. 12. She is numb from her toes down. 13. While in ER, she was examined, x-rated and sent home. 14. The skin was moist and dry. 15. Occasional, constant infrequent headaches. 16. Patient was alert and unresponsive. 17. Rectal examination revealed a normal size thyroid. (OMG! that is some examination) 18. She stated that she had been constipated for most of her life, until she got a divorce. 19. I saw your patient today, who is still under our car for physical therapy. 20. Both breasts are equal and reactive to light and accommodation. 21. Examination of genitalia reveals that he is circus sized. 22 The lab test indicated abnormal lover function. 23. Skin: somewhat pale but present. 24. The pelvic exam will be done later on the floor. 25. Patient has two teenage children, but no other abnormalities.
Posts.Title: Hospital and Doctor Diagnosis'- Funny For The Day

Posts.Content: Glad to hear that the cyber knife treatment wasn't so bad. Just the name scares me to death. You give me such hope as I look at my own prognosis. Two weeks ago today was my brain MRI, and I still haven't heard if they found anything.....makes me so angry. I hate to be a pest, but this waiting is beginning to get the best of us (my husband is as nervous as I am). It is just good to hear from you, and to hear that your experience was good. Hugs, and good thoughts you way. Judy
Posts.Title: Cyberknife was a BREEZE!!

Posts.Content: My thoughts and prayers are coming your way, Trish, and thank you TJ for passing along this information. Irish is in my thoughts, hoping that she can be strong, and fight the beast once more. Hugs, Judy
Posts.Title: Regarding Irishwhispers

Posts.Content: Prayers are coming your way. By the way, they do help, and there will be lots of people who post here who will add their prayers as well. Let us know how things progress. Hugs to you both, Judy
Posts.Title: prayers for my daughter

Posts.Content: Just recently my Texas State Representative's wife was diagnosed with cancer in both breasts, and when I spoke to her, I encouraged her to seek out the CSN site. She has since called me to say how much information she has gleened from this site, and how she will continue to use it as she goes through treatment. So far she hasn't posted, but I know that there is another supporter of CSN, and eventually I hope she will post herself. I am grateful to have found CSN, and can truly say it probably saved my life, if not my sanity. Thank you for your post. Hugs, Judy
Posts.Title: During a chat with the National Cancer Institute....

Posts.Content: As far as I am concerned, a portacath is the only way to go. I had mine put in just prior to the first chemo, and it was done under general anethesetic (?). Because of my size, (I am small across the chest area, and not much meat there either) it was a bit uncomfortable when I laid on my right side at night. As soon as chemo was over, I had it removed about two weeks later. It was removed under local anethesetic (again ?), and I was wide awake in the doctors office. Just didn't want to "go under" again. It was simple to come out, and didn't hurt at all. I would highly recommend a port to anyone undergoing chemo. Hope this helps. Hugs, Judy
Posts.Title: any thoughts on portacaths?

Posts.Content: Hey all, just wanted to share the good news of our family. We are the proud Great Grandparents of a new baby boy, Noah Adrian Martinez. He is the new addition to the family of my Granddaughter, Brittany and her husband Adrian. Since last year, we have been on a roller coaster ride, with Brittany giving birth in September 2009 to Casey Alexander. Little Casey passed away December 15, 2009, and Brittany was pregnant just a couple of months later (at the doctor's suggestion). Noah was born early (only 35 weeks gestation), but weighed in at 5 lbs 1 oz. and is very healthy. Both Brittany and Noah went home yesterday (Friday) after being born on October 24th. I have updated my Expressions Page to show a picture of the family if you would like to see our new little bundle. What a relief to have him here safe. Hugs to all, Judy
Posts.Title: Sharing Good News - New Great Grandson (Non-breast cancer related)

Posts.Content: Pat, I am so sorry to hear this news, and please know that I will certainly have you in my prayers until you receive the news....good or bad. If you do have to go through this treatment process again, at least you know what to expect, and if the news is good, then you have worried for nothing. I am keeping my fingers crossed that this is just a bump in the road. Keep us posted. Lots of hugs, Judy

Posts.Title: I Lost My Sister Today

Posts.Content: Would you believe....it is snowing in East Texas. We are expecting three to four inches tonight and early morning tomorrow. I know this doesn't compare to what you all are going through in the East, but for us, thi sis highly unusual. Just hope it stays snow and doesn't turn to ice. Good luck up there....we are staying by the fire and drinking our hot toddy....what a life. hugs. Judy
Posts.Title: SOCKED WITH SNOW......IN PHILADELPHIA

Posts.Content: Minetteg, I lived in the Houston area for many years, and most of my family is still there. There is a website, www.debakeydepartmentofsurgery.org, that is sponsored by Baylor College of Medicine, and specializes in surgeons who perform mastectomy surgeries regularly. These are associated with Michael DeBakey, a world renowned surgeon. This is only a suggestion, but the website does have names of surgeons that you might contact to see where they have privileges. Dr. Debakey performed open heart surgery on my father many years ago, and we always trusted anyone he was associated with. Good luck with your search. Another possibility would be to call M.D. Anderson and St. Lukes to get a referral directly from them. The Medical Center in Houston is one of the best in the world, and I am sure you will find a suitable surgeon. Your own oncologist or PCP would be a starting place also. Good luck to you in your quest to find medical care that you can be comfortable with. Hugs, Judy
Posts.Title: Need recomendations for Masectomy Surgeon - Houston, TX

Posts.Content: Although this comes as a shock to us all (you included), I have taken a couple of days to think about your earlier post. It reminds me of my first marriage, which lasted 18 years, and how when it came to an end I literally exhaled for the first time is many years. Your relationship is yours to make decision on, and believe me when I say that if anyone can do what is right for themselves, it is you. Your strength has allowed you to not only fight bc and colorectal cancer, but care for Hans when he has had his own medical issues. This takes such a toll on a relationship, although we don't mind being there for the one we love. Time does make changes in how our relationships develop, and we become complacent to things that would normally be small issues. In my own case, I was drifting through life, raising three children, and drifting further and further away from what should have been my main priority.....maintaining a healthy relationship with the one person in my life that should have been there through all that life threw at us. In the end, I knew I had made the right decision when I called him at his office, told him it was time we seriously sat down and talked about divorce, and he was silent for about 30 seconds (while I am hearing rustling in the background.) He finally said, "I think you are right....how about next Tuesday". Well, you can imagine how comfortable that made me feel. We lived in the same house, ate at the same table, attended functions with the children for the next seven days, and he finally "fit me into his schedule" to discuss ending our marriage. What I am trying to say is, only you and Hans know what truly takes place behind closed doors. Your decision is one that only you can make, and given that you have really faced reality over the past few years, you need not deprive yourself of true happiness in your life. I am in your corner, and know you will do what is best for you. Who knows, the beginning of your next journey may bring you to an even better place than you have ever been. Sending all of the hugs I can muster. Judy
Posts.Title: Off topic....may be my last dutch treat....sigh....

Posts.Content: Austingrl, welcome to the group, and know you are surrounded by individuals who have walked the path you have to look forward to traveling. Let's hope the biopsy shows nothing, but in case you need us further, you will always find someone who has "been there, done that" to assist you through the journey. I will have you in my thoughts and prayers. Let us know how things come out. Hugs. Judy P.S. I am from Jacksonville, TX, just southeast of Dallas. Lots of us Texans here, and always willing to help.
Posts.Title: Biopsy on Friday

Posts.Content: Tamara, please hang in there until you have a chance to sit with your onc and get the results directly from him. These reports we read are sometimes hard to decipher, and are especially complex even to the doctor. I know it doesn't sound so good, but it may be they will be watching you closely, and nothing is there just yet. Know that you will be held up by many until you have your visit. In the meantime, try to relax and keep those spirits up. Hugs, Judy

These reports we read are sometimes hard to decipher, and are especially complex even to the doctor. Posts.Title: Please just say a little prayer....

Posts.Content: One thing you might have your doctor check for is shingles. Depending on where the rash is located, some times this is a side effect of radiation. The immune system is compromised during chemo and radiation, and this is one of the more common problems that develop. I thought I had been bitten by a spider, as I broke out at my waist on my back. Because I couldn't see is very well by myself, I was relying on my husband to keep an eye on it. After about three days, I developed little blisters, and these turned into the shingles. A quick look by your doctor can tell what it may be, and if you catch it within 72 hours of breaking out, you can receive an innoculation that causes them to be much less harsh. Hopefully this is not what you are experiencing, but it never hurts to check it out. Good luck. Take care. Judy
Posts.Title: hives

Posts.Content: Margo, congratulations on getting through your first treatment. Sounds like you were on vacation....but we all know better. Check in with us to let us all know how you are doing for the next few days. Sending good thoughts to you, hoping that each day will bring you strength. Before you know it you will be finished with all of this. Don't forget to drink plenty of water to get that stuff out of your system. Hugs. Judy
Posts.Title: My first treatment

Posts.Content: I am so sorry for your loss, and can just see her "dancing the jig" with her Dad. Maybe my Dad will join in, as today is the 24th anniversary of his death. My heart goes out to you, as well as her family. Losses like this are hard to get past, but you know she is no longer in pain. I send you Irish hugs, Judy
Posts.Title: With a heavy heart..

Posts.Content: Hey Donna. Welcome to the best board on the net...one which includes all stages of cancer. This site is by far the best source of any kind of information you may seek, and lots of inspiration and hopefulness. If there is a question, someone on this board has been there, done that, and are perfectly willing to share their own personal experience. Like Moopy said, there is a site that has a thread specializing in Stage IV breast cancer patients, and it is helpful. This will primarily let you hear from ONLY Stage IV patients. The site is www.breastcancer.org. You might try there also, but please come back to this board when you need to talk, vent, scream, laugh, and be comforted by the real people who experience your pain. We are here for you. Hugs. Judy
Posts.Title: New to board

Posts.Content: Welcome home Joe and Moopy. Although I was also out of pocket for a couple of weeks, and just returned home yesterday, I had you guys in my thoughts every day, as well as all of the other members of this board. I know you are glad to have the tx behind you, and definitely glad to be back in familiar surroundings. Isn't "home" a nice place to be? Moopy, continue your recuperation, and take good care of yourself. Don't rush out to mow the lawn, or anything more strenuous than making yourself a nice hot cup of tea and lifting a book to sooth your spirit. As far as the "whirlwind" trip to all of the 50 states, that will come in time.....and I am envious but smiling. After all, we all look forward to doing those things that we postponed before starting this journey. Now it is time to get at making plans to be a part of the rat-race again. Hugs to you both (and the dogs of course). Judy
Posts.Title: Home from St. Louis... at last!

Posts.Content: The senseless loss of life is so hard to understand, especially since those of us on this board work so hard to stay alive at any cost. I know you are devastated, but know that you have a lot of people who are right here to hold your hand, help you vent, and hug you until you feel better. There is no explaining the acts of these brutal people who infiltrate our culture, and force upon us their will. I do hope who is responsible for this death will be found, prosecuted, and given the same treatment he gave. I would be the first to cast the first stone. How heartless, and how he has completely disregarded the feelings of others. I hope they find the culprit soon, and that you and your family have some peace. For now, just know you are held tightly by a large number of people who feel your pain, and are willing to do whatever it takes to make your world better. Hugs, Judy
Posts.Title: Im devastated....need prayers!!!!

Posts.Content: Sending good thoughts your way as you undergo treatment #2. One step closer to the end of chemo treatment. We will all have you on our minds tomorrow, and wish you well. Judy

Posts.Title: Im devastated....need prayers!!!!

Posts.Content: Hey Mimi...After returning from our two week vacation I have wondered why I couldn't find posts from you. Yours is always the first ones I read when I have missed a few days, and you were truly missed when I returned. The dulldrums are typical after completing all tx, especially the first two months following the end of rads. My onc told me that my body was trying to "zap back" to its normal potential, and the tx had put it into a state of not knowing what to do from day to day. Some checks in your blood levels could lead to an explanation of why you are down right now. Vitamin D3 was my culprit, and after getting on a regimine of a good D3 my body started responding. Maybe a call to your onc and a visit to have blood work done is something you need. Also, if you are taking any kind of meds, these will affect your moods. (I think they don't have you on an AI or Tamoxifen because you were ER negative). Any kind of sleeping aid, pain med, etc can cause depression, and can account for your mood. Enough rambling, but at least give these things some thought. We are all in your corner, and venting sometimes is just what you need to get back on track. Also, a good spa day wouldn't hurt. I am sending all my positive thoughts your way, as I am sure are many others. You are an inspiration, and deserve to be listened to whenever you have a need. Chin up, my girl....you are a winner, and things will get better. Hugs Judy
Posts.Title: I'm having a hard time...

Posts.Content: Seems like we are more than pink sisters.....my lumpectomy was on April 3, 2008, the same as yours. Looks like we have a lot in common. Coming up on three for us, and still I feel like crap...how about you? Happy New Year to all. Hugs, Judy
Posts.Title: Breast still tender 1yr later after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Surgery will be 3 years ago in April, and I still have a lot of tenderness in the incision area. My oncologist told me that some people never lose the pain in that area. (Something to look forward to, huh?) Sounds like lots of people have the continued tenderness, so nothing to worry about. Just keep telling your doctor when you have your visits to keep him aware of your condition, or if it gets worse. Hugs, Judy
Posts.Title: Breast still tender 1yr later after lumpectomy
